title: 113_hr2670
content: The "Openness in Political Expenditures Now Act" or the "OPEN Act" requires corporations and labor organizations to disclose information on disbursements for political activity to shareholders and members. The "OPEN Act" mandates corporations and labor organizations to disclose disbursements for political activity in regular reports to shareholders and members if the amount meets a certain threshold. The "OPEN Act" requires disclosure of disbursements for covered political activities, including the date, amount, candidate name and ID for independent expenditures, and the association or organization for other activities. The "OPEN Act" mandates disclosure of disbursements for covered political activities, including the recipient, Commission ID, and applicable thresholds for different types of activities. The "OPEN Act" requires corporations and labor organizations to submit a statement to the Commission containing information included in their reports to shareholders or members. This statement must include details on payments and contribution limitations as of the last day of the period. Additionally, if a corporation or labor organization maintains an Internet presence, they must post a hyperlink to this information. The "OPEN Act" mandates corporations and labor organizations to submit a statement to the Commission with financial details. If they have a website, they must post a hyperlink to this statement within 24 hours of the Commission posting it. The "OPEN Act" requires corporations and labor organizations to disclose their financial details on the Commission's website for a year after an election. Covered political activities include independent expenditures, electioneering communications, and payments to trade associations or 501(c)(4) organizations. The amendment defines terms like 'corporation', 'labor organization', and 'section 501(c)(4) organization'. It applies to reports filed after 90 days from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. LIMITATION ON COVERED POLITICAL ACTIVITIES BY SOCIAL WELFARE ORGANIZATIONS. The amendment to Section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code sets limits on political expenditures for entities, with a threshold of either 10% of total expenditures or $10,000,000. The entity's governing instrument must include provisions to enforce these limits. The amendment to Section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code defines 'covered political activity' as activities outlined in the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 and any payments made to entities or organizations for such activities. The amendment made to Section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code sets a threshold for exceeding 10 percent, with regulations to prevent asset transfers to avoid the threshold. Effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or amendment is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act and its amendments will not be affected.
